questions.correct_answer: D. When administering lidocaine, epinephrine, or vasopressin via the endotracheal tube, the dose should be diluted in 10 mL or normal saline or sterile water.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presented with complaints of a foreign body sensation in nose and frequent spitting of blood-tinged saliva for 6 months duration. On nasal endoscopy, mass was seen attached along the under surface of left inferior turbinate, which bled on contact. The patient also gave history of taking frequent baths in local ponds. A 6-year-old boy whose family recently immigrated from Bangladesh is brought to the pediatric OPD due to sore throat and fever. Physical examination shows mild tonsillar erythema with exudates. A sample from the exudates is obtained. On microscopic evaluation, there are clumped, gram positive bacteria with polar granules that stain deeply with aniline dyes. Which of the following best explains the pathogenicity of the organism most likely responsible for this patient's condition?

A 20-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a one-week history of painful swelling in her right axilla as shown in the image that was preceded by malaise, headaches, and night sweats. Temperature is 37.80 C , blood pressure is 126/78 mm Hg, and pulse is 88/min. Physical examination shows enlarged and tender epitrochlear and axillary lymph nodes on the right side. Histopathologic examination of a lymph node shows scattered necrotizing granulomas and stellate microabscesses containing pleomorphic, gram-negative coccobacilli. Which of the following is the most likely route of transmission of this patient's infection?
questions.correct_answer: D. Scratch from an infected cat

questions.text: A 39-year-old paraplegic man with an indwelling bladder catheter comes to the emergency department complaining of 24 hours of rigors, nausea, and vomiting. His temperature is 38.90 C. Physical examination shows suprapubic and costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows 3+ leukocyte esterase and numerous white blood cells. Urine and blood cultures grow non-lactose-fermenting Gram-negative rods. Colonies in nutrient agar shown in the image. Choose correct selective medium for this pathogen.

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease in FEV1 ≥ 20 % after 6 minutes of exercise

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in FEV1 ≥ 12 % following administration of inhaled bronchodilators

An unsupervised 2-year-old boy is found by his parents in the family garage near an open bottle of an unknown liquid. He is minimally responsive and is transported to the emergency department by ambulance. On physical examination, he has labored respiratory effort with diffuse wheezing and is somnolent. An arterial blood gas measurement with electrolytes is obtained, and the data are shown: Laboratory test pH 6.83 PCO2 47 mmHg PO2 100 mm Hg Sodium 142 mEq/L (142 mmol/L) Chloride 106 mEq/L (106 mmol/L) Bicarbonate 6 mEq/L (6 mmol/L) Of the following, the substance MOST likely ingested by the boy is

A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents with a rash and facial swelling. Her mother reports that they were at a family cookout when the girl was stung on the right arm by a bee. Within minutes she developed swelling, pain, and a raised, diffuse, red/ itchy rash. Her mother noted swelling of her lips and eyes. Soon after, the girl developed difficulty breathing and had nonbloody, nonbilious emesis once. No medications were given prior to her arrival. Her vital signs are a temperature of 37.6 º C, heart rate of 130 beats/min, respiratory rate 34 breaths/min, and blood pressure of 105/72 mm Hg. Her weight is 22 kg. She appears anxious and has clear rhinorrhea; periorbital edema; tachypnea with expiratory wheezes bilaterally; tachycardia; and multiple raised, erythematous lesions on her arms and trunk. Of the following, the BEST next step in the management of this child is administration of

options.label: B
options.text: Diphenhydramine, famotidine, and a corticosteroid orally

A previously healthy, 3-week-old girl, born at term, is admitted to the pediatric ward for fever of 38.9 °C. The neonate has been sleepy and not feeding well since the day prior to admission. Her temperature is 37.7 º C (after 1 dose of acetaminophen), heart rate is 180 beats/min, respiratory rate is 40 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation by pulse oximetry is 97% in room air. Her anterior fontanelle is bulging, capillary refill time is 4 seconds, and she is sleepy but arousable. Cardiac and respiratory examination findings are normal. A complete evaluation for sepsis is initiated, and appropriate antibiotic therapy is administered. Results of a complete blood count and basic metabolic panel are normal. Bacterial culture from the cerebrospinal fluid is positive the following day for Streptococcus pneumoniae. After 72 hours, blood and urine culture results are negative. Of the following, this child should MOST likely be evaluated for

questions.text: A woman with gestational diabetes mellitus is in labour. The estimated fetal weight is 4 kg. Her pelvis is adequate. She develops shoulder dystocia during the 2nd stage. What is the first step in the management?

options.label: A
options.text: Adduct and rotate the shoulders by internal manipulation.

options.label: B
options.text: Apply downward traction on the head.

options.label: C
options.text: Apply suprapubic pressure with uterine contractions.

options.label: D
options.text: Hyperflex and abduct the patient's hips.

questions.correct_answer: D. Hyperflex and abduct the patient's hips.

questions.text: A second para, whose first pregnancy had ended in an uncomplicated lower segment caesarean section, is admitted at a POA of 42 weeks. The fetus is in the cephalic presentation. The head is engaged. There are no uterine contractions. The cervix is about 2 cm long, posterior and the os admits the tip of the finger. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats per minute. She has no other pregnancy complications. What is the most appropriate management?

options.label: B
options.text: Insert a Foley catheter to ripen the cervix.

questions.text: A woman is admitted at 30 weeks of gestation following a sudden episode of antepartum hemorrhage of approximately 300 cc. The bleeding has ceased on admission. She is not pale, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg and the pulse rate is 76 beats per minute. The uterus is soft and non-tender. The fetus is in breech presentation. There are no palpable uterine contractions. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats per minute. What is the next step in the management?

options.label: C
options.text: Pelvic examination under anesthesia with all preparations ready for caesarean section.

questions.correct_answer: B. Ultrasound examination of the uterus.

questions.text: A primigravida who is admitted to the antenatal ward at 35 weeks is found to have a blood pressure of 160/110 mmHg. Her urine does not contain albumin. Which one of the following drugs should not be used in her management?
A woman, who has developed chickenpox 2 days ago, is admitted in labour. What is the best method to prevent infection in the neonate?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer varicella-zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) to the neonate soon after birth.

options.label: B
options.text: Administer varicella-zoster vaccine to the neonate.

questions.correct_answer: A. Administer varicella-zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) to the neonate soon after birth.

questions.text: A second para attends the antenatal clinic at a period of amenorrhoea of 10 weeks. Her first child has thalassemia major. What is the next step in the management?

options.label: A
options.text: Amniocentesis and DNA analysis of the fetus.

options.label: B
options.text: Analysis of cell-free fetal DNA in the maternal blood.

options.label: C
options.text: Chorionic villous sampling and DNA analysis of the fetus.

options.label: D
options.text: Estimation of carrier status in the father.

questions.correct_answer: C. Chorionic villous sampling and DNA analysis of the fetus.

questions.text: A primipara attends the antenatal clinic at 28 weeks. Her blood group is B rhesus negative. Her husband's blood group is rhesus positive. She does not have rhesus antibodies. What is the next step in the management?

options.label: D
options.text: Perform an ultrasound scan to determine the MCA peak systolic velocity.

questions.text: A woman with a monochorionic monoamniotic twin pregnancy attends the antenatal clinic at 34weeks. She has no other pregnancy complications. What is the most appropriate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Await spontaneous onset of labour till38 weeks.

options.label: B
options.text: Perform a caesarean section at 34 weeks after administering a course of corticosteroids.

options.label: C
options.text: Perform a caesarean section at 37 weeks.

options.label: D
options.text: Perform a cardiotocograph daily till 37 weeks.

questions.correct_answer: B. Perform a caesarean section at 34 weeks after administering a course of corticosteroids.

questions.text: A primipara complains of colicky lower abdominal pain at a period of amenorrhoea of 31 weeks. The fetus is in cephalic presentation. She is getting 2 uterine contraction per 10 minutes. On speculum examination, the approximate cervical dilatation is 2 cm. The membranes are intact. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats per minute. She has no other pregnancy complications. Transvaginal USS reveals a cervical length of 14 mm. What is the next step in the management?

options.label: A
options.text: Allow labour to progress without interference.

options.label: B
options.text: Commence intramuscular corticosteroids and oral nifedipine.

questions.correct_answer: B. Commence intramuscular corticosteroids and oral nifedipine.

questions.text: A woman, who had a normal delivery 3 days ago, complains of lower abdominal pain, fever and offensive vaginal discharge. Her temperature is 39°C, pulse rate is 130 beats per minute and the blood pressure is 100/70mm Hg. What is the most important next step in the management?

A woman with mitral stenosis is in the first stage of labour. The cervical dilatation is 4 cm and she is getting 2 uterine contractions per 10 minutes. She is in New York Heart Association Grade 2. Her ejection fraction is 60%. The fetal heart rate is 150 beats per minute. What is the most appropriate method of analgesia?

A 30-year-old second para, who has been diagnosed to have antiphospholipid syndrome, attends the antenatal clinic at a POA of 6 weeks. She has had early onset severe pre-eclampsia during the previous pregnancy. A live healthy baby was delivered by LSCS at 33 weeks. This was followed by three spontaneous abortion at 9 weeks. What is the best management option for her?

options.label: A
options.text: Commence aspirin and LMWH 40 mg once daily.

options.label: B
options.text: Commence aspirin immediately and continue throughout the pregnancy.

questions.correct_answer: A. Commence aspirin and LMWH 40 mg once daily.

Aspirin is being given to a person who had 1st MI on 14th Feb 2023; is which type of prevention?

A study is being done to follow up 30,000 people for 30 years; 1200 cases developed and for every case which developed 1:1 control was allotted at the same time from those who were non diseased. The type of study design is:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Case Control Studies Based in A defined Cohort Properties
  • • • Predominantly a type of cohort study (due to a forward direction)
  • • • Advantages:
  • • • Problem of recall bias is eliminated.
  • • • Advantage of temporality is maintained.
  • • • Economical (Done for rare diseases + whose diagnostic tests are very expensive)
  • • • Greater comparability (as both cases & controls are derived from the original cohort)
  • • • Disadvantage: non diseased persons from whom the controls are selected may not be fully representative of original cohort, due to death or failure to follow up cases
